Overall, the teaching assistant for this course was accessible, organized, and able to explain concepts clearly and thoroughly.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?

narratives.question_text: Please identify the teaching assistant with whom you interacted most closely _____________________ .
comments: Instructor: Jill Roberta Kelly  (Jill)
Instructor: Jill Roberta Kelly  Jill Kelly
Instructor: Jill Roberta Kelly  Jill
Instructor: Jill Roberta Kelly  Jill Kelly
Instructor: Jill Roberta Kelly  Jill Kelly.

narratives.question_text: What were the strengths and weaknesses of your teaching assistant
comments: Instructor: Jill Roberta Kelly  Jill was genuinely invested in ensuring that students learned, and she made herself accessible through office hours and Piazza. I didn't take advantage of her help as often as I could have, but it was comforting to know that the help would be there if and when I needed it.
Instructor: Jill Roberta Kelly  Jill went above and beyond to help the students, both during in person meetings and through answering questions posted on Piazza.
Instructor: Jill Roberta Kelly  Very quick to respond to questions raised
Instructor: Jill Roberta Kelly  -Jill is patient and willing to explain concepts. She was a lifeline for many students in this course.

Instructor: Jill Roberta Kelly  Jill is an excellent, knowledgable, and hard-working TA. She is immensely helpful and friendly in office hours and the StatsLab and on Piazza. I learned a lot from my interactions with her.

Instructor: Jill Roberta Kelly  Jill is excellent working one-on-one. Definitely go to her office hours if you take a course for which Jill is a TF. She also sometimes replies to e-mails and/or the Piazza course site -- and these replies can be helpful, too, although I recommend in-person, which is worth the effort. Jill is enthusiastic and supportive.

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: While Professor Tomlin was very accessible, I found that we were required to do many assignments with little feedback. There were no objective benchmarks for work or assignments, and I feel like a member of the teaching staff should have reviewed our weekly assignments. I did not get anything more out of the course than from the course materials, which were well composed.

I think the course was too ambitious in trying to cover Earth Engine and ArcGIS-related Phython in one semester. The material is fascinating, useful and a good accompaniment to the Vector and Raster GIS courses.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: We developed tangible products and could see our progress throughout the course.
Hands-on experience with code relevant to my academic and research interests.
Dana has a very clear and deliberate way of teaching.
Successfully running code
-Working one-on-one with Jill Kelly

Dr. Tomlin is fascinating to listen to. He explains difficult concepts with an elegance and dramatic flair that is wonderful and rare. The material is incredibly useful and well-balanced between Google Earth Engine and ArcGIS. The materials are well-organized, the ungraded homework assignments are great, and the sample codes are very useful.
Strengthens geospatial, programming and project completion skills.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: I really didn't get much out of the lectures. I think it would be helpful to make them a bit more interactive.

This course would be well-served in lab environment. I don't believe that this material is best taught through lecture. Additionally, the instructor could have done a better job of introducing students to the basics of coding, as no prior knowledge was stated as a necessary prerequisite.

- I feel both ArcGIS and Google Earth Engine covered in this class are oriented for students who have an interest in land use type of subject, not so much for those interested in social science subjects - Language used to explain codes in the handouts is hard to understand. Not intuitive at all. I was not able to understand much from the explanation unless I run the codes.
Sometimes the freedom of the homework assignments was daunting. It takes almost as long to come up with a homework idea as it does to actually carry out that idea.
Might be useful to conduct the course in a computer lab so everyone can follow along

-The classroom culture of this course was one in which students neglected to speak up and ask questions due to the fear of being judged by the professor and/or other students. Collaboration among students was minimal. For next year, I strongly encourage the professor to have students introduce themselves to each-other and the professor at the beginning of this course - this is simple but it makes a huge difference. It would also be helpful to divide students into small groups that are required to meet weekly to go over the codes together. -For most of the semester, this class met for three hours straight with one ten-minute break. I recommend that more breaks be offered and that the lecture be shortened (max 2 hours) to allow students to absorb the material. Small group work in class would also help to keep the students alert and engaged. -This course was billed as an introductory geospatial programming class, but basic concepts of coding were not explained. This led to much confusion at the beginning of the semester for students. I suggest that the professor refer students to specific resources/ chapters in a textbook that align with each lecture so that students who do not have a background in coding can better prepare for class.
Clearer expectations and instructions for assignments, feedback on weekly assignments.

*The grading scheme (ranking the whole class) is alarming and not very helpful. A regular grade and a few comments would help me better understand the quality of my work. *Due dates and a rubric or description for the 2 final assignments should be available online. I wasn't able to find anything like this. *The class is a little too long, so I appreciated that Dr. Tomlin often ended early. *In the Python section, I felt like we spent too much time on the subjects in the first few weeks and not enough time on practical applications. Realistically, it is hard to see myself writing a full algorithm from scratch, and it would have been useful to see more examples of how to use Python to implement, combine, and modify existing tools and algorithms.
The Earth Engine handouts are weak in that they don't really explain much. Their internal linking is good.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: N/A
There were no discussion/lab sections.

We are in the room for three hours yet are often told, "don't try to follow along on your computer." I understand the need to plow through a lot of material, but lecture-listening is the worst way for most people to learn. What a waste of a 3-hour stretch of time wherein skills could be developed, knowledge exchanged and learning accomplished by doing.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: I'm trying to build out my quantitative and programming skills, and the course helped dramatically with both.
I am very interested in incorporating geospatial analysis into my work and understanding the coded aspects of the software makes doing such analyses much more efficient.
I think this is essential for anyone wishing to study environmental phenomena with any kind of spatial component
It fits well. GIS and geospatial work is developing at rocket pace and is so important to environmental work. I am pursing many things geospatial and things related thereto in conservation.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: See 20: I'm trying to build out my quantitative and programming skills, and the course helped dramatically with both.
I've taken both the vector and raster courses and want to incorporate spatial analysis into my professional work in the future, so this course seemed to be the last step in the progression.
Geospatial software design is a very applicable, technical skill.
I was intrigued with the course description
-I already had a strong background in ArcGIS and wanted to learn how to increase the functionality of the program.
Repeated: GIS and geospatial work is developing at rocket pace and is so important to environmental work. I am pursing many things geospatial and things related thereto in conservation.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: The course gave me a certain comfort in working with the material I wanted to learn. I don't feel like I gained quite as much in-depth technical knowledge as I was hoping to.

No. While the weekly homework assignments were useful and the most effective aspect of the class, the material seemed disjointed and didn't follow a structure that allowed for overall understanding of coding for geospatial use, as a whole.
Yes. I wish there was a second whole course on this material to get even more practice.
Yes
-No
No, I thought the course would provide more than a rote toolkit

Yes and no. Earth Engine is not really well developed enough yet, and the handouts were often difficult to follow. Python, and the study materials for it, were better developed, although still challenging. More groundwork for Python would be appreciated.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: N/A

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: The course focuses on how to develop geospatial software, in other words, using codes to realize your goals. Be aware.
You can get as much or as little out of this class as you'd like. If you don't have programming experience, though, you should probably expect to go up a bit of a learning experience.
Consider taking the vector and raster courses beforehand. Only take the course if you plan to incorporate geospatial analysis into your work in the future.
Take this if you have GIS experience and want to expand your GIS skills. Great class!
Take the course
-I cannot recommend this course.
Take it. Start immediately. Ask a lot of questions, if you need to -- in class, on the Piazza site, at office hours for either the TF or Dana Tomlin. The skills one can develop are invaluable.
